trans-unit.source: Wraps ActiveX controls and exposes them as fully featured Windows Forms controls.
You typically do not use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class directly.

You can use the [Aximp.exe (Windows Forms ActiveX Control Importer)](~/docs/framework/tools/aximp-exe-windows-forms-activex-control-importer.md) to generate the wrappers that extend <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost>.

The ActiveX Control Importer generates a class that is derived from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class, and compiles it into a library file (DLL) that can be added as a reference to your application.
Alternatively, you can use the `/source` switch with the ActiveX Control Importer and a C# file is generated for your <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> derived class.
You can then make changes to the code and recompile it into a library file.

If the name of a member of the ActiveX control matches a name defined in the .NET Framework, then the ActiveX Control Importer will prefix the member name with "Ctl" when it creates the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> derived class.

For example, if your ActiveX control has a member named "Layout", it is renamed "CtlLayout" in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> derived class because the `Layout` event is defined within the .NET Framework.
Most of the common properties of the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class are only valid and used if the underlying ActiveX control exposes those properties.

A few examples of the common properties are <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.BackColor%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Cursor%2A>, <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Font%2A>, and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Text%2A>.
If you are using Visual Studio as your Windows Forms design environment, you can make an ActiveX control available to your application by adding the ActiveX control to your Toolbox.
To accomplish this, right-click the **Toolbox**, select **Customize Toolbox**, then browse to the ActiveX control's.ocx file.
For more information, see "Adding ActiveX Controls to Windows Forms" in the Visual Studio documentation.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class, wrapping the ActiveX control indicated by the specified CLSID.
The CLSID of the ActiveX control to wrap.
Initializes a new instance of the class, wrapping the ActiveX control indicated by the specified CLSID, and using the shortcut-menu behavior indicated by the specified flags value.

If the binary representation of the `flags` parameter value contains the bit represented by the value 0x1, the shortcut menu for the control will not contain an **Edit** option unless the ActiveX control explicitly provides it.

If the binary representation of the `flags` parameter value contains the bit represented by the value 0x2, the shortcut menu for the control will contain a Properties option if the ActiveX control offers a set of property pages; otherwise, the shortcut menu will contain a Properties option only if the ActiveX control explicitly provides it.
The CLSID of the ActiveX control to wrap.
An <xref href="System.Int32"></xref> that modifies the shortcut-menu behavior for the control.
When overridden in a derived class, attaches interfaces to the underlying ActiveX control.
This member is not meaningful for this control.
A Color that represents the background color of the control.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.BackColorChanged"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.
If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.BackColorChanged> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.
The events derived from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class are not supported by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class.
The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
This property is not relevant for this class.
The background image displayed in the control.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.BackgroundImageChanged"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.
If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.BackgroundImageChanged> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.
The events derived from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class are not supported by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class.
The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
This property is not relevant for this class.
An <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImageLayout"></xref> value.
This event is not relevant for this class.
Begins the initialization of the ActiveX control.
Design environments typically use this method to start the initialization of a component that is used on a form or used by another component.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.EndInit%2A> method ends the initialization.
Using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.BeginInit%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.EndInit%2A> methods prevents the control from being used before it is fully initialized.
The initialization occurs at run time.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.BindingContextChanged"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.
If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.BindingContextChanged> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.
The events derived from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class are not supported by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class.
The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ChangeUICues"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.
If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ChangeUICues> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.
The events derived from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class are not supported by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class.
The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.Click"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.
If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.Click> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.
The events derived from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class are not supported by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class.
The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
Gets or sets the control containing the ActiveX control.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ContainingControl%2A> property value can be different from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Parent%2A> property.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl> represented by this property is the ActiveX control's logical container.

For example, if an ActiveX control is hosted in a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.GroupBox> control, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.GroupBox> is contained on a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>, then the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ContainingControl%2A> property value of the ActiveX control is the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Form>, and the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control.Parent%2A> property value is the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.GroupBox> control.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ContainerControl"></xref> that represents the control containing the ActiveX control.
This property is not relevant for this class.
The shortcut menu associated with the control.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ContextMenuChanged"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.
If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ContextMenuChanged> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.
The events derived from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class are not supported by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class.
The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
Creates a handle for the control.
Called by the system to create the ActiveX control.
The CLSID of the ActiveX control.
An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> representing the ActiveX control.
Gets the required creation parameters when the control handle is created.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.CreateParams"></xref> that contains the required creation parameters when the handle to the control is created.
Called by the control to prepare it for listening to events.
This base-class implementation is empty.
This property is not relevant for this class.
The foreground color of the control.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.CursorChanged"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.

The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
Gets the default size of the control.
The default <xref href="System.Drawing.Size"></xref> of the control.
Destroys the handle associated with the control.
Called by the control when it stops listening to events.
This base-class implementation is empty.
Releases the unmanaged resources used by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control"></xref> and its child controls and optionally releases the managed resources.
`true` to release both managed and unmanaged resources; `false` to release only unmanaged resources.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.DoubleClick"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.

Requests that an object perform an action in response to an end-user's action.
This method passes the specified verb to the [IOleObject::DoVerb](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=166076) method of the hosted control.
One of the actions enumerated for the object in IOleObject::EnumVerbs.

This method is not supported by this control.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Bitmap"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Drawing.Rectangle"></xref>.
Returns a value that indicates whether the hosted control is in edit mode.
`true` if the hosted control is in edit mode; otherwise, `false`.
This property is not relevant for this class.
A <xref href="System.Boolean"></xref> value.

Using the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.BeginInit%2A> and <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.EndInit%2A> methods prevents the control from being used before it is fully initialized.
The initialization occurs at run time.
This property is not relevant for this class.

If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ForeColorChanged> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.

The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
Returns a <xref href="System.Drawing.Color"></xref> structure that corresponds to the specified OLE color value.
The OLE color value to translate.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Color"></xref> structure that represents the translated OLE color value.
Returns a <xref href="System.Drawing.Font"></xref> created from the specified OLE [IFont](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=166075) object.
The IFont to create a <xref href="System.Drawing.Font"></xref> from.
The created from the specified [IFont](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=166075), if the font could not be created, or `null` if font is `null`.
Returns a <xref href="System.Drawing.Font"></xref> created from the specified OLE [IFontDisp](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=166073) object.
The IFontDisp to create a <xref href="System.Drawing.Font"></xref> from.
The created from the specified [IFontDisp](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=166073), if the font could not be created, or `null` if font is `null`.
Returns an OLE [IFontDisp](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=166073) object created from the specified <xref href="System.Drawing.Font"></xref> object.
The font to create an IFontDisp object from.
The [IFontDisp](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=166073) object created from the specified font or `null` if font is `null`.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Font.Unit"></xref> property value is not <xref href="System.Drawing.GraphicsUnit.Point"></xref>.
Returns an OLE [IFont](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=166075) object created from the specified <xref href="System.Drawing.Font"></xref> object.
The font to create an IFont object from.

The [IFont](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=166075) object created from the specified font, or `null` if font is `null` or the [IFont](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=166075) could not be created.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Font.Unit"></xref> property value is not <xref href="System.Drawing.GraphicsUnit.Point"></xref>.
Returns an OLE `IPictureDisp` object corresponding to the specified <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> to convert.
An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> representing the OLE `IPictureDisp` object.
Returns an OLE `IPicture` object corresponding to the specified <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref>.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Cursor"></xref>, which is an image that represents the Windows mouse pointer.
An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> representing the OLE `IPicture` object.
Returns an OLE `IPicture` object corresponding to the specified <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref>.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> to convert.
An <xref href="System.Object"></xref> representing the OLE `IPicture` object.
Returns an OLE Automation date that corresponds to the specified <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref> structure.
An OLE Automation date is implemented as a floating-point number whose value is the number of days from midnight, 30 December 1899.

For example, midnight, 31 December 1899 is represented by 1.0; 6 A.M., 1 January 1900 is represented by 2.25; midnight, 29 December 1899 is represented by -1.0; and 6 A.M., 29 December 1899 is represented by -1.25.
The base OLE Automation Date is midnight, 30 December 1899.
The maximum OLE Automation Date is the same as <xref:System.DateTime.MaxValue>, the last moment of 31 December 9999.
For more information about OLE Automation, see the [MSDN Library](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=37118).
The <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref> structure to translate.
A double-precision floating-point number that contains an OLE Automation date equivalent to specified time value.
The value of this instance cannot be represented as an OLE Automation Date.
Retrieves a reference to the underlying ActiveX control.
An object that represents the ActiveX control.
Returns an OLE color value that corresponds to the specified <xref href="System.Drawing.Color"></xref> structure.
The <xref href="System.Drawing.Color"></xref> structure to translate.
The OLE color value that represents the translated <xref href="System.Drawing.Color"></xref> structure.
Returns an <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> corresponding to the specified OLE `IPicture` object.
You can use this method to convert `IPictureDisp` objects in addition to `IPicture` objects.
This works because the `IPictureDisp` OLE interface is a subset of the `IPicture` interface.
Converting `IPictureDisp` objects with this method is necessary because the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.GetPictureFromIPictureDisp%2A> does not work correctly at this time.
The `IPicture` to convert.
An <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> representing the `IPicture`.
Returns an <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> corresponding to the specified OLE `IPictureDisp` object.
This method does not work correctly.

You can use the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.GetPictureFromIPicture%2A> method to convert an `IPictureDisp` object into an <xref:System.Drawing.Image>, however, because the `IPictureDisp` OLE interface is a subset of the `IPicture` interface.
The `IPictureDisp` to convert.
An <xref href="System.Drawing.Image"></xref> representing the `IPictureDisp`.
Called by the system to retrieve the current bounds of the ActiveX control.
ActiveX controls scale themselves, so this method does not perform any special calculations, ignores the `factor` and `specified` values, and returns the `bounds` value unchanged.
The original bounds of the ActiveX control.
A scaling factor.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BoundsSpecified"></xref> value.
The unmodified bounds value.
Returns a <xref href="System.DateTime"></xref> structure that corresponds to the specified OLE Automation date.
The `date` parameter is a double-precision floating-point number that represents a date as the number of days before or after the base date, midnight, 30 December 1899.

The sign and integral part of `date` encode the date as a positive or negative day displacement from 30 December 1899, and the absolute value of the fractional part of `date` encodes the time of day as a fraction of a day displacement from midnight.
`date` must be a value between negative 657435.0 through positive 2958466.0.
Note that because of the way dates are encoded, there are two ways of representing any time of day on 30 December 1899.

For example, -0.5 and 0.5 both mean noon on 30 December 1899 because a day displacement of plus or minus zero days from the base date is still the base date, and a half day displacement from midnight is noon.
For more information about OLE Automation, see the [MSDN Library](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=37118).
The OLE Automate date to translate.
A that represents the same date and time as date.
The date is not a valid OLE Automation Date value.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.GiveFeedback"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.
If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.GiveFeedback> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.
The events derived from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class are not supported by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class.
The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
Gets a value indicating whether the ActiveX control has an **About** dialog box.
The **About** dialog box typically displays version and copyright information about the ActiveX control.
`true` if the ActiveX control has an **About** dialog box; otherwise, `false`.
Determines if the ActiveX control has a property page.
Property pages allow an ActiveX control user to view and change ActiveX control properties.

These properties are accessed by invoking a control properties dialog box, which contains one or more property pages that provide a customized, graphical interface for viewing and editing the control properties.
`true` if the ActiveX control has a property page; otherwise, `false`.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.HelpRequested"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.
If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.HelpRequested> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.
The events derived from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class are not supported by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class.
The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
This property is not relevant for this class.
An <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.ImeMode"></xref> value.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ImeModeChanged"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.
If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ImeModeChanged> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.
The events derived from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class are not supported by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class.
The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
Attempts to activate the editing mode of the hosted control.
Determines if a character is an input character that the ActiveX control recognizes.

The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.IsInputChar%2A> method is called during window message preprocessing to determine whether the given input character should be preprocessed or sent directly to the ActiveX control.
The preprocessing of a character includes checking whether the character is a mnemonic of another control.

As implemented in the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class, the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.IsInputChar%2A> method always returns `true`, so the specified character is sent directly to the ActiveX control.
The character to test.
`true` if the character should be sent directly to the ActiveX control and not preprocessed; otherwise, `false`.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.KeyDown"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.
If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.KeyDown> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.

The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.

The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.Layout"></xref> event is not supported by the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> class.
If you attempt to add or remove a handler for the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.Layout> event, a <xref:System.NotSupportedException> is thrown.
The events derived from the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.Control> class are not supported by the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> class.
The events exposed by the ActiveX control when the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost> wrapper is created are the events that should be used.
Announces to the component change service that the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost"></xref> has changed.
This event is not relevant for this class.

Preprocesses keyboard or input messages within the message loop before they are dispatched.
A <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Message"></xref>, passed by reference, that represents the message to process.
The possible values are WM_KEYDOWN, WM_SYSKEYDOWN, WM_CHAR, and WM_SYSCHAR.
`true` if the message was processed by the control; otherwise, `false`.
Processes a dialog key.
One of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Keys"></xref> values that represents the key to process.
`true` if the key was processed by the control; otherwise, `false`.
Processes a mnemonic character.
The character to process.
`true` if the character was processed as a mnemonic by the control; otherwise, `false`.
Returns a value that indicates whether the hosted control is in a state in which its properties can be accessed.
`true` if the properties of the hosted control can be accessed; otherwise, `false`.

Calls the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ShowAboutBox"></xref> method to display the ActiveX control's About dialog box.
The <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.SetAboutBoxDelegate%2A> method also allows derived classes to handle the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ShowAboutBox%2A> method without attaching a delegate.
This is the preferred technique for handling the <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.ShowAboutBox%2A> method in a derived class.
The <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.AboutBoxDelegate"></xref> to call.
Performs the work of setting the specified bounds of this control.
The new <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Left"></xref> property value of the control.
The new <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Top"></xref> property value of the control.
The new <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Width"></xref> property value of the control.
The new <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control.Height"></xref> property value of the control.
A bitwise combination of the <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.BoundsSpecified"></xref> values.
Sets the control to the specified visible state.
`true` to make the control visible; otherwise, `false`.
Displays the ActiveX control's **About** dialog box.
If <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.HasAboutBox%2A> is `false`, no **About** dialog box is displayed.
Displays the property pages associated with the ActiveX control.
If <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.HasPropertyPages%2A> is `false`, no property pages are displayed.
Property pages allow an ActiveX control user to view and change ActiveX control properties.

These properties are accessed by invoking a control properties dialog box, which contains one or more property pages that provide a customized, graphical interface for viewing and editing the control properties.
Displays the property pages associated with the ActiveX control assigned to the specified parent control.
If <xref:System.Windows.Forms.AxHost.HasPropertyPages%2A> is `false`, no property pages are displayed.
Property pages allow an ActiveX control user to view and change ActiveX control properties.

These properties are accessed by invoking a control properties dialog box, which contains one or more property pages that provide a customized, graphical interface for viewing and editing the control properties.
The parent <xref href="System.Windows.Forms.Control"></xref> of the ActiveX control.
Gets or sets the site of the control.
The <xref href="System.ComponentModel.ISite"></xref> associated with the Control, if any.

Returns the default property for the current object.
A <xref href="System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor"></xref> that represents the default property for the current object, or `null` if the object does not have properties.
